I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan of 
up to $40,000,000 (or its yuan equivalent) to Zhujiang Financial Leasing Company Limited (ZFL) 
for the Zhujiang Financial Leasing Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises Finance Project in the 
People’s Republic of China (PRC). 
 
2.  The project entails the Asian Development Bank (ADB) providing longer-tenor financing 
to ZFL for lease finance to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in the PRC. ADB’s 
financing will support ZFL’s funding requirements for long-term funding for SMEs, which is in short 
supply.  ADB’s  support  will  enable  the  company  to  provide  longer-tenor  lease  finance  to 
underserved segments, improve its asset–liability profile, and diversify its funding sources. 
 
II.  THE FINANCIAL INTERMEDIARY 
 
A.  Investment Identification and Description 
 
3.  Overview of access to finance by small and medium-sized enterprises. SMEs are an 
important part of the PRC economy. The development of SMEs directly contributes to economic 
growth, given their critical role in creating jobs. Small businesses with 300 or fewer employees 
accounted for 98.64% of all firms and contributed more than 60% of total gross domestic product 
(GDP), 50% of tax income, 75% of job creation, and 68% of exports.1  Despite the significant 
contribution of SMEs to economic growth, limited access to finance has always been a major 
constraint on SMEs. Banks have shown a preference for lending to state-owned enterprises 
(SOEs) and larger corporates operating in the priority sectors identified in domestic industrial 
policy, as SMEs are considered a higher-risk segment with higher transaction costs. Since 2011, 
the  Government  of  the  PRC  has  implemented  various  initiatives  to  improve  the  business 
environment for SMEs and facilitate their access to finance, including amending the Law on 
Promoting Small and Medium-sized Enterprises and developing small banks and non-deposit-
taking financial institutions. Despite government initiatives, many SMEs are still marginalized in 
access to financing. The financing gap for micro and SMEs in the PRC reached $1.89 trillion in 
2017, accounting for 17% of GDP.2 
 
4.  Financial leasing industry. Leasing is particularly suited for SME financing, especially to 
purchase equipment, which is not generally accepted as collateral by commercial banks. The 
PRC’s leasing industry grew rapidly at a compound annual growth rate of 24.85% in 2008–2019, 
filling the gap that traditional banks do not bridge. Despite rapid growth, the financial leasing 
industry needs further development. The lease penetration rate was 1.71% in 2019, ranking it 
24th out of the top 50 global leasing markets.3 
 
5.  Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on small and medium-sized enterprises. The 
outbreak of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic in 2020 has adversely impacted SMEs 
in the PRC. They are vulnerable to shocks because of their financial weakness, lower degree of 
business diversification, smaller size, and lower ability to withstand temporary disruption in 
production and services. SMEs are generally not as digitalized as other firms, making them less 
resilient and flexible in adapting to changes in work processes to respond to the business

environment during the pandemic. The government has introduced policy measures to support 
SMEs,  including  raising  central  bank  relending  and  rediscounting  quotas,  and  directionally 
lowering the deposit reserve ratio of the People’s Bank of China to encourage banks to lend more 
to SMEs at lower interest rates. Despite this policy support, SMEs continue to face difficulty in 
accessing finance. As of June 2020, credit to SMEs accounted for only 28.86% of total bank 
loans.4 
 
6.  Rationale. ADB’s nonsovereign operations projects in the PRC’s finance sector have 
actively supported leasing, targeting diverse subsectors in underdeveloped segments, including 
SME financing.5 In 2018, ADB disbursed a $60 million loan (in CNY equivalent) to ZFL for SME 
finance in the underdeveloped central and western regions of the PRC,6 and the loan proceeds 
have been successfully deployed. The COVID-19 outbreak has exposed significant challenges 
for SME development, reducing jobs, especially for migrant workers from rural areas, who 
typically work in services and light manufacturing. CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED. 
 
7.  CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED. Guangdong’s Pearl River Delta area alone 
had 44.2 million migrant workers in 2019 or 25% of all migrant workers in the PRC.7 Almost all 
migrant workers are employed by SMEs, which accounted for 98.4% of total enterprises in 
Guangdong. The COVID-19 pandemic has significantly impacted SMEs and jobs for migrant 
workers; 8 million migrant workers are estimated to have lost their urban jobs on a long-term basis 
and resettled in their native regions because of the COVID-19 outbreak.8 SMEs in Guangdong 
face significant challenges in accessing finance. Loans to all private enterprises in Guangdong 
accounted for 28.0% of the total outstanding banking sector loans in that province by the third 
quarter of 2020, while loans to SMEs accounted for only 10.4%.9 Lack of collateral is a key 
constraint on SMEs’ access to finance, and unsecured loans to SMEs accounted for only 9.1% of 
total SME loans and 0.95% of total banking sector loans in Guangdong. The province has 
substantial regional disparity in economic development and significant income inequality. In 2019, 
the total GDP of Guangzhou and Shenzhen cities accounted for 46.9% of total GDP of the entire 
province.10 Of the 21 cities in Guangdong, 14 had a per capita GDP that was below the national 
average of CNY71,965 ($10,300). Shenzhen, the most developed city, had a GDP per capita that 
was 10 times more than that of Meizhou ($29,627 versus $2,963). This project will help expand 
ZFL’s capacity to finance SMEs, particularly those outside the most developed cities—Beijing, 
Guangzhou, Shanghai, and Shenzhen—increasing jobs and reducing regional income inequality.

C.  Ownership, Management, and Governance 
 
Ownership. ZFL is a wholly owned subsidiary of GRCB. Excluding the big 5 state-owned banks and the 
12 national joint-stock commercial banks, GRCB is one of the larger local banks and ranked fourth among 
all rural commercial banks by total assets in 2019. By June 2020, GRCB had total assets of CNY972 billion 
and total deposits of CNY727 billion. GRCB is rated Baa2 by Moody’s and has been listed on the Hong 
Kong Stock Exchange since 2017 with market capitalization of HK$6 billion as of 19 March 2021. GRCB 
has  a  diversified  shareholder  structure.  Its  largest  beneficial  owner  is  the  Guangzhou  municipal 
government, with a total shareholding of 18.22% through 13 SOEs. The remaining shareholders are mainly 
private sector entities and individual investors. No other shareholders directly or indirectly hold more than 
a 5% stake in GRCB. ADB conducted integrity due diligence on ZFL and its shareholders, board of directors, 
and key managers.11 Although ZFL’s beneficial owners could not all be identified, the potential risk is 
mitigated by the fact that GRCB’s relevant shares are held by public and institutional investors, and no 
shareholder other than the government holds more than a 5% indirect stake in GRCB. ADB’s review does 
not give ADB cause to believe that the entity is being used for money laundering or terrorism financing. Tax 
integrity due diligence was not required because the transaction does not involve intermediate jurisdictions 
or material related-party transactions.12 
 
11.  CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED.   
 
12.  Governance structure. ZFL has a well-defined corporate governance structure. The 
board of directors is responsible for overall strategy, major decisions, key business objectives, 
and senior management appointments. Since ZFL is a fully owned subsidiary of GRCB, all 
directors are appointed by GRCB. CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED. The board has 
four  committees,  for  related-party  transactions  control,  strategic  development,  risk,  and 
performance review. CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED.

III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  The Assistance 
 
13.  ADB will provide a senior secured loan to ZFL of up to $40 million (or its yuan equivalent), 
with a tenor of up to 5 years.  
 
B.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  Use of proceeds. ZFL will use the proceeds of the ADB debt financing to fund lease 
contracts with SMEs in the PRC. The project will exclude SMEs located in the four most developed

cities—Beijing, Guangzhou, Shanghai and Shenzhen—from using ADB loan proceeds. The 
project will use the government’s definition of SMEs.13 For lease finance to SMEs, the maximum 
amount funded by the proposed loan will be capped at $8 million per sub-project. The proposed 
loan is also expected to fund the pilot of a new lease finance product for micro-enterprises that 
ZFL plans to launch in late 2021. 
 
15.  Reporting arrangements. ADB will monitor the project over its life. ZFL will provide ADB 
with financial and other reports at predetermined regular intervals and as requested, including 
(i) quarterly unaudited financial statements, (ii) annual audited financial statements, (iii) quarterly 
compliance certificates for financial covenants, (iv) periodic reports on the underlying leases 
financed by ZFL through the loan, and (v) annual reports on the selected development indicators 
and the safeguards and social dimensions policy agreed between ADB and ZFL. 
 
16.  Evaluation. ADB will prepare monitoring reports regularly and at least annually. The first 
report will be submitted no later than 12 months after the first loan disbursement. 
 
C.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
 
17.  Provide  long-term  stable  finance.  CONFIDENTIAL  INFORMATION  DELETED.  To 
diversify its funding sources, ZFL issued one bond, through which it raised CNY1 billion in April 
2019. However, a bond issuance is subject to long regulatory approval, and the company will not 
be able to tap the capital markets again without fresh approval from regulators. The long-tenor 
funding from ADB will enable the company to provide longer-tenor leasing products for SMEs and 
improve its asset–liability profile, increasing the company’s capacity to expand its operations. 
 
18.  Support  development of innovative  financing  modality  for  SMEs and  facilitate 
knowledge transfer. Leasing is a modality particularly suited to finance SMEs, especially for 
procurement of manufacturing equipment, which is not generally accepted as collateral by 
commercial banks. By supporting a leasing company with a strong SME focus, the proposed loan 
will help expand SMEs’ access to lease finance and, in turn, support job creation and economic 
growth.  The  project  will  support  ZFL to  pilot  a  new  lease  finance  product targeting micro 
enterprises, and ADB will also facilitate knowledge transfer and information exchange between 
ZFL and leasing companies operating in other ADB’s developing member countries. 
 
19.  Support gender equity. ADB will work with ZFL to promote gender-inclusive measures 
in operations. ZFL will create a respectful working environment by introducing anti–sexual-
harassment  measures  and  creating  opportunities  for  women  by  hiring  female  interns  and 
providing professional development training for female staff members. 
 
20.  Mobilize  cofinancing  and  supporting  safeguards  capacity  development.  ADB 
expects to mobilize additional cofinancing for the project and has been arranging a $40 million 
parallel loan from Deutsche Investitions- und Entwicklungsgesellschaft mbH (DEG). Cofinancing

IV.  DEVELOPMENT IMPACTS AND STRATEGIC ALIGNMENT 
 
A.  Development Impacts, Outcome, and Outputs 
 
21.  Impacts. The project is aligned with the following impacts: (i) access to lease finance for 
SMEs  through  financial  leasing  improved,14 and  (ii)  financial  leasing  industry  developed.15  
Despite their importance in job creation and output generation, SMEs still face significant barriers 
to accessing credit from financial institutions. The project will promote SMEs’ access to finance 
and contribute to economic growth. By providing longer-tenor finance to a small leasing company, 
the project will support the development of the financial leasing industry in the PRC, where the 
leasing penetration rate was only 1.71% in 2019, lower than in major developed markets. The 
project extends ADB’s support to the leasing industry beyond the top-tier leasing companies 
typically financed by ADB. 
 
22.  Outcome. The project will have the following outcome: sustainability of ZFL’s SME leasing 
operations improved. 
 
23.  Outputs. The project will have the following outputs: (i) ZFL’s capacity to extend lease 
financing to SMEs increased, (ii) skills development opportunities for ZFL’s female staff members 
improved, and (iii) gender inclusiveness of ZFL’s work environment increased. 
 
B.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
 
24.  Consistency with ADB strategy and country strategy. The project supports ADB’s 
Strategy 2030 operational priorities 1 (tackling remaining poverty and reducing inequalities) and 
2 (accelerating progress in gender equality).16 The project aligns with ADB’s Strategy 2030 
Operational Plan for Priority 2 Accelerating Progress in Gender Equality, 2019–2024.17 The 
project is consistent with ADB’s country partnership strategy, 2021–2025 for the PRC, which 
emphasizes expediting access to financing for private companies, particularly SMEs.18  
 
25.  Consistency with the sector strategy and relevant ADB operations. The project is 
aligned with the Review of ADB’s Financial Sector Operational Plan, which notes that ADB will 
support financial inclusion of the traditionally underserved, such as SMEs.19 The plan calls for 
increased support to leasing and other finance subsectors, which supplement commercial banks 
and play an important role in improving SMEs’ access to finance. ADB’s strengthened poverty

V.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
 
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions 
 
26.  ADB has categorized the project in compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement 
(2009).21 
 
27.  Category FI. ADB has assessed the potential environmental and social (E&S) risks 
associated with ZFL’s existing and likely future portfolio, and its commitment and capacity for E&S 
management. ZFL is an existing ADB client, and it has established and maintained an ESMS 
satisfactory to ADB that includes procedures to (i) screen transactions against ADB's prohibited 
investment  activities  list,  (ii)  categorize  investments  to  exclude  those  having  significant 
environmental and/or social impacts (category A), and (iii) ensure that investments using ADB 
loan proceeds comply with applicable ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009) requirements 
and national laws and regulations. ZFL’s Environmental and Social Responsibility Committee, 
headed by senior management, is responsible for the establishment of the ESMS and its 
integration into company processes, and oversees the implementation of the ESMS risk mitigation 
measures  by  business  development  managers  in  the  processing  and  monitoring  of  lease 
contracts. 
 
28.  During due diligence, ADB reviewed the E&S annual monitoring reports, which include 
subprojects financed using proceeds from an earlier ADB loan. The review confirmed that ZFL 
has  developed  an  ESMS  implementation  guide,  provided  ESMS  training  to  relevant  staff 
members  to  support  ESMS  implementation,  and  implemented  the  ESMS  screening  and 
categorization procedures in the subprojects previously financed by ADB. Through its company 
website, ZFL provides avenues to raise concerns and grievances related to its operations. The 
company monitors reputational risks throughout its portfolio by engaging an external data service 
provider to regularly check on legal disputes involving its clients, including any labor-related 
cases. The lease portfolio of ZFL involving SMEs is not expected to have significant adverse 
environmental or social impacts, given that most of the leases are for equipment or facilities. 
Nevertheless, the capacity of the in-house team to identify environmental, health and safety, and 
social risks can be further strengthened by providing additional ESMS training. ZFL has indicated 
that it would welcome additional support and, as such, ADB plans to work with the other 
development finance institution cofinancier to develop an ESMS training package tailored for the 
company’s specific needs. 
 
29.  ZFL will continue to include the following information in the annual monitoring reports it 
submits to ADB: (i) the nature of subprojects and categorizations, (ii) compliance with safeguard 
and social requirements, and (iii) compliance with applicable national and international laws and 
standards. ZFL will continue to ensure compliance with national labor laws and, pursuant to ADB’s 
Social Protection Strategy (2001), take measures to comply with the internationally recognized

30.  Some gender elements. To promote gender equality and/or women’s empowerment in 
its business activities, following ADB’s Policy on Gender and Development (1998), ZFL commits 
to  (i)  increase  the  number  of  women  in  its  internship  program,  (ii)  provide  professional 
development training to at least half  of its female staff members, (iii) include anti–sexual-
harassment provisions in its staff conduct guidance, and (iv) train staff members on the new anti–
sexual-harassment provisions. ZFL will submit periodic reports on implementation of gender 
measures to ADB. 
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy 
 
31.  ZFL was advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best international practice relating to 
combating corruption, laundering money, and financing terrorism. ADB will ensure that the 
investment  documentation  includes  appropriate  provisions  prohibiting  corruption,  money 
laundering, and the financing of terrorism; and remedies for ADB in the event of noncompliance. 
 
C.  CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED  
 
D.  Assurances 
 
32.  Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank (the Charter),22 
ADB will proceed with the proposed assistance upon establishing that the Government of the 
PRC has no objection to the proposed assistance to ZFL. ADB will enter into suitable finance 
documentation, in form and substance satisfactory to ADB, following approval of the proposed 
assistance by the ADB Board of Directors. 
 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
33.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loan of up to 
$40,000,000 (or its yuan equivalent) from ADB’s ordinary capital resources to Zhujiang Financial 
Leasing  Company  Limited  for  the  Zhujiang  Financial  Leasing  Small  and  Medium-Sized 
Enterprises Finance Project in the People’s Republic of China, with such terms and conditions as 
are substantially in accordance with those set forth in this report, and as may be reported to the 
Board.

metadata.Subject:
The project entails the Asian Development Bank (ADB) providing longer-tenor financing to Zhujiang Financial Leasing Company Limited (ZFL) for lease finance to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in the People's Republic of China. ADB’s financing will support ZFL’s funding requirements for long-term funding for SMEs, which is in short supply. ADB’s support will enable the company to provide longer-tenor lease finance to underserved segments, improve its asset–liability profile, and diversify its funding sources.

The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.

This document dated April 2021 is provided for the ADB project 54459-001 in the People's Republic of China.
metadata.Title: Zhujiang Financial Leasing Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises Finance Project: Report and Recommendation of the President
